text.p: Base metal prices made substantial gains to steal the show on the world commodities markets after a spate of investment fund buying against a backdrop of waning stocks. Zinc was the star of the day.
Copper made gains to break resistance at $2,380.
Prompt crude rode as high as $20.38. Precious metals also gained. Wheat prices closed higher in U.S. trading on continued good export demand after a Japanese buy of 60,000 tonnes.
Base metal prices made substantial gains to steal the show on the world commodities markets after a spate of investment fund buying against a backdrop of waning stocks.

Zinc was the star on the LME as it zoomed to 4-1/2 year highs of $1,328 per tonne by midday, up from the previous close of $1,287. As zinc pulled ahead, aluminium rose nine dollars to chalk up a six-week high of $1,672 per tonne. On Wednesday it had it jumped $29 on good fund-based demand and a fall in warehouse stocks.
Copper also made gains to break key resistance at $2,380, rising $13 on the open to an intraday high of $2,387 per tonne by the midsession.

Metals analysts said the jump in the price of zinc was no surprise due to the tight supply situation and expected further rises in the future. Zinc has already risen 26 percent ($300) since the start of the year.

"We think zinc prices could peak out this time next year at 85 cents/lb ($1,873/tonne)," said Nick Moore, a London-based metals analyst for Flemings Global Mining Group. "It's a genuinely tight market."
"The general expectation is that much of the previously huge inventory overhang will have been eroded by the latter part of 1997," brokers Billiton said in a report issued on Thursday.
Nickel built on morning strength. Last trade at $7,700 was $160 above the kerb.
Last trades or bids for key Australian-interest commodities.
Copper Grade A (LME cash official US$/tonne) 2442 ( 2425)
Zinc High Grade (LME cash official US$/tonne) 1304.5 ( 1261)
